title: Richard Skinner and Jen Dalton Draft Kings lineups Week 5
text:
Richard Skinner and Jen Dalton Draft Kings lineups Week 5 
Updated: Fri, Oct 09 2015, 02:44 PM 
CINCINNATI (Richard Skinner) -- Local12 reporter Jen Dalton and I are playing fantasy football this season at DraftKings.com and a little further below are the lineups we selected for the Millionaire Maker contest for games that will be played on Sunday and Monday. 
Draft Kings offers one week contests that don't lock participants into season-long teams and the contest in which we are participating doesn't include the Thursday night game, which will be the case almost every week this season. 
Our lineups will be on Local12.com each Friday and you can see us explain our picks each Saturday night on Bengals Nation, which starts at 11:35 p.m. on Local12. 
Here are our lineups and my explanation below (you can see Jen's reasoning and more of mine on Bengals Nation) in addition to a rating system for Bengals players' fantasy value this week (note: you can't see lineups on our mobile app, so go to desktop to view): 
RICHARD SKINNER 

WHY I MADE MY SELECTIONS 
The Skinny: I have come extremely close to cashing each of the last two weeks after a modest return in week two and going with a different tact this week of trying to spread the money out at each position rather than grab one star and piece together the rest to stay under the cap. 
Palmer threw for over 300 yards in three of the first four games and at least two touchdown passes in three of the first four games. 
Bell should get upwards of 30 touches both as a runner and a receiver, and Forsett is not only coming off a big game against the Steelers, but is going against a Cleveland defense that has been woeful against the run (141.5 yards per game and 4.8 yards per carry allowed). 
Fitzgerald has seemingly found a Fountain of Youth and had at least six receptions and at least 87 yards in each of the first four games. It also gives me a chance to pair him with Palmer. Evans is simply due to produce and is facing a weak Jacksonville secondary. Benjamin was taken with hopes of Cleveland being forced to play catch up and because of how poor the Baltimore secondary has been at times this season. Maclin is starting to become a real weapon for Kansas City. 
Daniels is facing an Oakland defense that has struggled against tight ends. 
The Chiefs are an average defense, but love the matchup against a horrid Chicago offense. 
BENGALS FANTASY VALUE 
Each week I rate the Bengals fantasy players value on the following system: touchdown means must play; field goal means it's a good play; first down means play only if you have to play him; punt means don't play at all: 
Touchdown (must play): The Bengals have been fantastic offensively this season, but they are facing a defense that hasn't allowed a touchdown in the last two games. 
Field Goal (good play): WR A.J. Green (he is a must-play virtually every week, but this isn't one of them; iwould be hard to believe you have two receivers better than Green on your roster and if you do and that's all you need to start then maybe it's time to sit Green, otherwise you should probably play him). QB Andy Dalton (he's off to a great start and despite the defense he is facing he's probably a better play than any other quarterback you might have); RB Jeremy Hill (had three touchdowns against Kansas City and is top candidate around the goal line, but wouldn't expect a lot from him this week); TE Tyler Eifert (he is arguably a top five fantasy tight end so would be hard to believe you have someone better on your roster, but after big opener has just seven receptions for 118 yards in last three games combined); Defense/Special Teams (if your league counts sacks then this would be a very good play, because Seattle allowed 18 sacks in the first four games, plus the Seahawks aren't exactly an offensive juggernaut). 
First Down (play only if you have to play him): RB Giovani Bernard (has been outstanding in his role the first four games and had a TD last week, but not a lot of fantasy value); K Mike Nugent (he's a candidate to be a solid producer each week because of the Bengals offense); WR Marvin Jones (he was a major disappointment in the Kansas City game dropping a 54-yard TD pass and is facing one of NFL's best secondaries);. 
Punt (don't play at all): WR Mohamed Sanu (he just doesn't get enough targets to justify it). 
Follow us on Twitter @Local12 and LIKE us on Facebook for updates! 
To get "The Skinny" on local sports be sure to follow Local12 Digital Sports Columnist/Editor Richard Skinner on Twitter @Local12Skinny and LIKE him on Facebook for updates or email him raskinner@sbgtv.com. Related Stories
